College of New Energy China University of Petroleum (East China) 66 West Changjiang Road Qingdao PR China A series of MnO x -CuO catalysts were fabricated by redox precipitation (MnCu-YH), hydrothermal (MnCu-SR), and oxalate complexation methods (MnCu-LH) for low-temperature CO oxidation. The results showed that the MnCu-YH achieved 100 % CO conversion at 175 ℃ with WHSV of 60000 ml/ (g·h). It was also observed that SO2 could deactivate the catalyst, while H2O could delay the toxicity. Through the characterization of HR-TEM, XRD, BET, it was found that MnCu-YH possessed a typical nanorod structure and the largest specific surface area, measured at 45.54 m2·g−1. XPS and H2-TPR analyses revealed that MnCu-YH had the highest ratio of adsorbed oxygen and Mn3+, and excellent redox capacity, which were due to the redox cycle formed by Mn ions and Cu ions (Cu+ + Mn4+ ↔ Cu2+ + Mn3+). This redox cycle could strengthen the metal interaction between Mn and Cu, which is the fundamental factor driving the strong CO oxidation activity of MnCu-YH. Besides, CO-TPD investigation showed that MnCu-YH has the most CO adsorption sites and is more likely to adsorb CO. A catalytic mechanism for CO oxidation was proposed depending on in-situ DRIFTS characterization. As the adsorption site of CO, Cu+ formed CO-Cu+ species, which reacted with surface reactive oxygen species to produce CO2, and MnO x participated in the reaction by changing its oxidation state to cause oxygen transfer. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MnCu bimetallic catalyst CO catalytic oxidation Preparation method CO oxidation mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO is a prevalent air pollutant found in various environments. High levels of CO in the air may pose a threat to human health [1,2]. CO mainly comes from the incomplete combustion of fossil fuels and emissions from vehicles and industry. In recent years, three-way catalysts have been extensively used to remove CO and CH compounds from automobile exhaust, which greatly reduces its CO emission. However, reducing CO emissions has become a critical priority, particularly in the iron and steel industry. As a key step in steel production, the sintering process is the largest contributor to CO emissions, significantly impacting air quality. Therefore, it is particularly important to explore a feasible method to reduce CO emission from flue gas. In CO purification technologies[3–5], the most effective, economical, and environmentally pleasant purifying technique is catalytic oxidation. Currently, researchers have designed and developed various catalysts, including noble metal (Pt [6,7], Ag [8], Au [9], Pd [10], Ir, Ru [11])-based catalysts, transition metal (Mn [12–14], Cu [15,16], Co [17])-based catalysts. Recently, many catalysts based on transitional metal oxides have been developed because of their superior CO oxidation characteristics, affordability, and environmentally nontoxicity. Among them, Mn-based catalysts, like Mn-Fe and Mn-Ce have been extensively researched for the removal of CO due to their exceptional oxygen mobility and superior redox properties [18–23]. The Cu-MnO x catalyst prepared by Pan et al. [24] achieved complete oxidation of CO at 175 ℃. It was demonstrated that the active center of copper could enhance the redox performance of the catalyst. Zhang et al. [25] also observed that introducing transition metal Cu into CeO2 might increase mental interaction and the creation of oxygen vacancies. Therefore, it was indicated that well-mixed Mn-Cu bimetallic oxides may show excellent activity for low-temperature CO oxidation. Among the factors affecting catalyst activity, preparation method is an important one [26–29]. Herein, various MnCu catalysts were prepared via a redox precipitation, hydrothermal, and oxalic acid complexation method and compared in CO oxidation performances. Additionally, the catalyst's stability in the existence of SO2 or H2O was examined. The focus of this work was put on the effects of various methods on physicochemical properties and the adsorption behavior of the catalyst and oxidation processes of CO were thoroughly explored. XPS, XRD, HR-TEM, BET and H2-TPR were applied to investigate the relationship between Mn and Cu and properties of all preparation methods. In the meantime, the oxidation mechanism of CO was investigated by in-situ DRIFTS and XPS. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 MnCu− YH catalysts The catalysts known as MnCu-YH were made by the redox precipitation process. Solution A was generated by dissolving 0.5 g of NaOH in 20 ml of ethanol and deionized water. 1.52 g of KMnO4 and 0.38 g of Cu (CH3COO)2 were dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water to obtain Solution B. Solution C was obtained by slowly adding solution A to solution B. After that, solution C was heated for 12 h at 140 ℃. Following the completion of the hydrothermal process, the sediment underwent multiple washings using deionized water. The resultant materials were then dried for 12 h at 80 ℃ and calcined for 2 h at 450 ℃. 2.1.2 MnCu− SR catalysts The sample labelled as MnCu-SR was obtained employing a hydrothermal technique. 2.38 g Mn (NO3)2·6H2O and 0.38 g Cu (NO3)2⋅4H2O were dissolved in 60 mL ethylene glycol to form a transparent solution through ultrasound for 30 min. Subsequently, CH3COONa (7.0 g) and polyethylene glycol (1.9 g) were added to the solution and rapidly stirred for an additional 30 min using ultrasound. The solution was kept at 180 ℃ for 12 h in a 100 mL Teflon-lined container. Following multiple ethanol washes, the slurry samples were dried at 60 ℃ and calcined for 4 h at 300 ℃. 2.1.3 MnCu− LH catalysts The catalyst was made by the oxalate complexation process named MnCu-LH. 4.59 g Mn (NO3)2⋅6H2O and 0.9 g Cu (NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, 11.25 g of oxalic acid was added to the aqueous mixture. The solution was then heated at 80 ℃ in a water bath while being agitated to form the transparent gel. The resultant materials were dried for 72 h at 80 ℃ and then calcined for 3 h at 400 ℃. 2.2 Catalyst characterization In this work, a variety of techniques were employed to analyze the prepared catalysts, consisting of XRD, HR-TEM, SEM, BET, XPS, EPR, H2-TPR, CO-TPD, and in-situ DRIFTS. Detailed methodologies for these characterizations are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The CO catalytic activity was evaluated in a fixed reactor. The gas mixture consists of 1 % CO, 16 % O2, 50 ppm SO2 (when employed), 10 % H2O (when employed), and N2. The weight hour space velocity (WHSV) was 60,000 ml/(g·h). Detailed information of catalytic activity testing is exhibited in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity The catalytic performance of MnCu-YH, MnCu-SR, and MnCu-LH catalysts were comparatively investigated for CO oxidation reaction in the temperature range of 25–300 ℃, and the CO activity curves are shown in Fig. 1 . When the temperature was between 25 and 100 ℃, the order of CO activity was MnCu-YH > MnCu-SR≈ MnCu-LH. MnCu-YH showed the best low-temperature activity. When the temperature was between 100–200 ℃, the order of CO activity was MnCu-YH > MnCu-SR > MnCu-LH. The order of temperature required for the catalyst to achieve 100 % conversion was MnCu-YH (175 ℃) > MnCu-SR (200 ℃) > MnCu-LH (225 ℃). When the catalyst achieved maximum conversion, the CO conversion was maintained at 100 % even if the temperature was continued to rise. In conclusion, MnCu-YH contributed the best CO conversion among the three catalysts. 3.2 Stability evaluation In practical flue gas, SO2 and H2O commonly exist meantime, which may affect the activity of the catalyst. Therefore, as illustrated in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 , the stability of the catalyst was evaluated in the presence of 50 ppm of SO2 or 10 % H2O. As shown in Fig. 2, all catalysts were deactivated, and the rate of deactivation was MnCu-LH > MnCu-SR > MnCu-YH when 50 ppm SO2 was introduced into the gas flow. SO2 was found to be easily adsorbed on metal oxide catalysts to form hydroxides and sulfates, resulting in a decrease in catalyst activity [30–34]. After SO2 was cut off, the CO conversion of MnCu-YH did not recover, and the CO conversion of MnCu-LH and MnCu-SR recovered to 18 % and 19 %, respectively within 2 h. It might be ascribed to the decomposition of sulfate partially deposited on the catalyst surface. on Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst, Yan et al. [35] also discovered a similar phenomenon. It can be seen from Fig. 3 that when SO2 and H2O were injected at the same time, the rate of catalyst activity reduction is slower than that when only SO2 was injected, showing that the existence of H2O may delay the poisoning of the catalyst. A similar phenomenon was found by Xu et al. [33] on Pt/W-Ti catalyst and Zhao et al. [36] on Au/CeO2 catalyst. It has been shown that the reaction between *OH by H2O dissociation and CO could promote CO catalytic oxidation [31]. 3.3 Textural properties Fig. 4 depicts the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of the samples. All catalysts displayed IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, in which the adsorption volume increased obviously in high pressure stage. It indicated that the catalyst's pore structure was irregular [37]. Furthermore, the average pore size of all catalysts ranged from 2 to 50 nm, indicating the formation of mesoporous structures, which would favor heterogeneous reaction [37]. Table 1 presentes the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of the catalysts. As can be shown, MnCu-YH has the smallest average pore diameter and the highest pore volume. The order of BET specific surface area is MnCu-YH (45.54 m2/g) > MnCu-SR (10.48 m2/g) > MnCu-LH (10.13 m2/g). It is consistent with the activity sequence (MnCu-YH > MnCu-SR> MnCu-LH). It may be attributed to the fact that an increase in the BET specific surface area of the material enhances the likelihood of gas molecules interacting with the catalyst, which in turn improves catalytic performance [38]. 3.4 Morphology and phase analysis The morphology and textural properties of all samples were further analyzed using HR-TEM and SEM, as displayed in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 . MnCu-YH exhibits a typical nanorod structure (Fig. 5a1 ). The (400), (420) and (211) planes of α-MnO2 belong to lattice fringes of 0.25, 0.22 and 0.24 nm, respectively. The (111) plane of Cu1.4Mn1.6O4 can be identified lattice fringes of 0.17 nm. MnCu-SR is composed of stacked nanoparticles (Fig. 5b1 ). As shown in Fig. 5b3 , the (111) and (11–2) planes of CuO were observed. The 0.48 and 0.49 nm lattice fringes correspond to the (200) plane of α-MnO2 and the (101) plane of CuMn2O4. MnCu-LH is formed from spherical deposits (Fig. 5c1 ). In Fig. 5c3 , the crystal faces of α-MnO2 phase (200) and (220) and Cu1.4Mn1.6O4 phase (111) and (220) were observed. As can be seen from Fig. 6, Mn, Cu and O elements were uniformly dispersed in all samples. The results reveal that the synthetic method can influence the morphology and crystal phase of the catalyst. The phase compositions of all samples were examined through X-ray diffraction, and the resultant XRD patterns are presented in Fig. 7 . A clear tetragonal structure of α-MnO2 (PDF#44–0141) was observed in all samples. The characteristic peaks of MnCu-YH and MnCu-LH copper oxides were not prominent, suggesting that Cu ions disperse on the surface of α-MnO2 without forming large grains [39]. However, MnCu-SR mainly showed the characteristic peak of CuO. Combined with the HRTEM results, the catalyst generated via hydrothermal strategy is not conducive to the dispersion of copper. Research has demonstrated that the degree of Cu dispersion also affects the CO oxidation activity of the catalyst [39]. The phase compositions of all samples after sulfur resistance test were examined through X-ray diffraction, and the resultant XRD patterns are presented in Fig. 8 . The samples of MnCu-YH, MnCu-SR and MnCu-LH after sulfur resistance test were designated as MnCu-YH-S, MnCu-SR-S and MnCu-LH-S, separately. Before and after sulfur resistance test, the position of diffraction peaks was nearly identical in all samples, but the peak intensity was significantly reduced. This was because the metal is sulfated, resulting in a reduction in peak strength. The drop of MnCu-YH-S peak strength was significantly higher than that of other catalysts, which could explain the low activity of MnCu-YH after sulfur resistance test. In addition, the surface of the catalyst will form sulfate after the introduction of SO2. However, the characteristic diffraction peak of sulfate was not observed, which could be attributed to the less sulfate produced. Therefore, it was not in the detection range. 3.5 Elemental analysis The surface chemical properties and metal valence states of the catalyst were characterized by XPS. The Mn 2p, Cu 2p, and O 1s spectra of all catalysts are displayed in Fig. 9 . The XPS spectra of O 1s for all catalysts are depicted in Fig. 9(a). With the exception of MnCu-YH, the O 1s spectra of all catalysts could be separated into two peaks. Lattice oxygen (Oα) was identified as the peak at the lower binding energy (∼528.7 eV), and adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) was considered as the peak at the higher binding energy (∼530.9 eV) [40,41]. For MnCu-YH, the peak located at 533.4 eV was attributed to hydroxyl oxygen (Oλ) [42]. According to the calculation of peak area proportion, the fraction of surface adsorbed oxygen to total surface oxygen was determined and recorded in Table 2 . The adsorbed oxygen ratios of MnCu-YH, MnCu-SR, and MnCu-LH samples are 32.26 %, 29.91 %, and 28.01 %, respectively. It can be noticed that the adsorbed oxygen content in MnCu-YH sample reaches the highest level, which is in line with its outstanding catalytic activity. Therefore, it indicates that a direct relation between the amount of adsorbed oxygen in the sample and catalytic performance of the material, which was also obtained by Liu et al [38]. It has been proved that adsorbed oxygen possesses a beneficial and efficient boosting impact on the catalytic oxidation performance of the material. The high proportion of Oβ indicates that more oxygen vacancies are generated in the catalysts [43]. Given the higher mobility and reactivity [43] of Oβ, it is beneficial to the oxidation of CO [44]. In Fig. 9(b), two distinct peaks in the Mn 2p spectra are observed near 642.3 and 654 eV, which belong to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 spin orbital peaks, separately. Significant satellite peaks are observed at 648.4 eV for all catalysts, indicating the presence of Mn2+ [45,46]. Mn 2p1/2 is deconvolved into three separate peaks, which attribute to Mn2+ (∼652.1 eV), Mn3+ (∼654.1 eV) and Mn4+ (∼656.1 eV), correspondingly. In the same way, Mn2p3/2 is deconvolved into three distinct peaks, which belong to Mn2+ (∼640.5 eV), Mn3+ (∼642.1 eV) and Mn4+ (∼643.6 eV), correspondingly. It indicates that Mn species exist in the three catalysts as Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ states [47–49]. As shown in Table 2, the proportion of Mn3+ in MnCu-YH, MnCu-SR, and MnCu-LH are 58.86 %, 52.81 % and 44.15 %, respectively. The proportional order of Mn3+ is exactly in line with the sequence of the catalyst activity. It was well established that the high Mn3+ content is more likely to form oxygen vacancies rich in reactive oxygen species, which is beneficial of the redox conversion between Mn3+ and Mn4+ [50,51]. To verify this conclusion, EPR was employed to detect unpaired electrons in all catalysts, providing further insight into the variations in oxygen vacancy concentration. Fig. 9(d) presents the EPR spectra for each catalyst. All three catalysts exhibited symmetrical sharp isotropic signals at approximately g = 2.003, which was indicative of electron trapping at oxygen vacancies. Among them, the MnCu-YH catalyst displayed the most intense signal, suggesting it has the highest concentration of oxygen vacancies, followed by MnCu-SR and MnCu-LH. As shown in Fig. 9(c), the Cu 2p spectra for all catalysts shows multiple peaks. The peaks near approximately 961 and 942.1 eV belong to oscillating satellite peaks, which indicates the presence of Cu2+ [52–54]. The peaks of Cu 2p3/2 spin-orbit binding energy near 933.2 and 934.8 eV is the characteristic peak of Cu+ and Cu2+ [55]. The XPS spectra of Cu 2p reveals that the sample's surface is in a state of coexistence of Cu2+ and Cu+. When coupled with Mn 2p spectra, the charge conversion between the related oxides facilitates the redox reaction of Cu+ + Mn4+ ↔ Cu2++ Mn3+, which can create more oxygen defects [56]. Combined with other results, it is revealed that the metal interaction between Mn and Cu produces more surface oxygen and defects, which are key factors contributing to the formation of huge CO oxidation properties [57]. 3.6 Reducibility and CO adsorption properties To assess the catalyst's reducibility, H2-TPR experiment was conducted, and H2-TPR results obtained are shown in Fig. 10(a) and Table 3 . MnCu-YH catalyst presented two primary reduction peaks at 303 ℃ and 336 ℃, which belonged to the reduction process of Mn4+→Mn3+ and Mn3+→Mn2+, separately. It indicates that manganese oxides are generally reduced in two steps: MnO2→Mn2O3→Mn3O4→MnO (Mn4+→Mn3+→Mn2+). Mo et al. [45] and Luo et al [58]. had also demonstrated this result. The two peaks observed at low temperature correspond to the reduction process of Cu2+→Cu+→Cu0 in the CuO sample. Table 3 reveals that Cu was reduced easily than Mn because the initial temperature for Cu reduction was lower compared to that of Mn reduction. As observed from Table 3, the temperature sequence corresponding to all reduction peaks is MnCu-YH < MnCu-SR < MnCu-LH. And the consumption of H2 showed MnCu-YH (10.82 mmol·g−1) > MnCu-SR (10.51 mmol·g−1) > MnCu-LH (9.93 mmol·g−1). The upward trend in H2 consumption and the shift of the reduction peak towards low temperature can indicate that the catalyst's redox capacity has been improved. The order of reducing intensity is MnCu-YH > MnCu-SR > MnCu-LH. This is consistent with the activity sequence, indicating that reducibility is directly related to catalytic performance. According to XPS analysis, the reversible charge conversion of Cu++Mn4+↔Cu2++Mn3+ improves the reducibility of the synthetic material. This indicates that the metal interaction between Mn and Cu will cause the reduction peak of the catalyst to move towards low temperature. This was also proved by Lykaki et al. [59] on Cu/CeO2 catalyst. For purpose of further investigating the adsorption and desorption properties of the synthesized catalyst for CO, CO-TPD was conducted. Fig 10(b) confirms that all prepared samples exhibited an initial CO2 desorption peak at 100–300 ℃. As illustrated, the intensity of the CO consumption peak over MnCu-YH and MnCu-SR in various synthesized catalysts is significantly higher than MnCu-LH. The peak of MnCu-YH is noticeably wider, indicating that the catalyst contains more CO adsorption sites and proving its strong CO adsorption and desorption ability [60]. Compared with MnCu-SR (177 ℃), the initial temperature of CO2 desorption peak of MnCu-YH catalyst is lower (172 ℃), indicating easier CO adsorption on MnCu-YH [61]. In fact, even this observation may support the high CO conversion of MnCu catalysts at low temperature. 3.7 CO catalytic mechanism So as to better understand the CO adsorption behavior, in-situ DRIFTS measurements were applied to study the CO adsorption and desorption processes of these three catalysts. In situ DRIFTS spectra was acquired at various time intervals during CO + O2 co-adsorption, and the findings are presented in Fig. 11 . It could be seen from Fig. 8 that all catalysts have a characteristic absorption peak at 2120 cm−1, which is due to CO adsorbed onto the Cu+ sites [62,63]. Additionally, the gaseous CO peak appeared near 2174 cm−1 [64]. And the absorption peak of CO2 is found around 2350 cm−1 [64,65]. CO2 absorption peaks were detected for the other two catalysts except MnCu-SR catalyst. The above results show that MnCu-SR catalyst undergoes a simple adsorption-desorption equilibrium without significant redox reactions at room temperature. In contrast, both the MnCu-YH and MnCu-LH catalysts engage in redox reactions with the reaction gas at room temperature. In MnCu-YH catalyst, absorption peaks associated with surface carbonates were found at 1600 and 1506 cm−1 [66]. Fig. 12 displays in-situ DRIFTS spectra of the catalyst during heating with CO + O2 co-adsorption. The intensity of the CO2 absorption peak gradually increases with temperature, while the CO absorption peak decreases, suggesting that CO adsorbed on the catalyst surface could be activated and oxidized at high temperature. When the temperature reached the final test value of 250 ℃, CO peak disappeared, suggesting that the catalyst had enough reactive oxygen species to completely oxidize CO. It was reported that Cu+ is more effective than Cu2+ in adsorbing and activating CO [59,67]. Cu+ generates more active sites on the catalyst surface, facilitating the production of CO-Cu⁺ species. Subsequently, the quick oxygen transfer through the redox system (Cu+ + Mn4+↔Cu2+ + Mn3+) and the effective activation of O2 by OVs can accelerate the catalytic oxidation of CO. Moreover, during the pyrolysis process, the peak at 1037 cm−1 comes from carboxyl salt (COO−), the infrared absorption peaks associated with carbonates and other species are observed in the 1200–1600 cm⁻¹ range [66,68]. Specifically, the peak at 2140 cm−1 is derived from carbonate (CO3 2−). The absorption peaks at 1405 and 1587 cm−1 can be regarded as the υ (C-h) and υ (C-O) vibrations in -CH3 and bildentate carbonates, suggesting that CO combines with surface oxygen to generate intermediate carbonates and then CO2. Depending on in-situ DRIFTS and XPS results, a reaction mechanism for CO catalyzed by MnO x -CuO catalyst is proposed. As the adsorption site of CO, Cu+ forms CO-Cu+ species, which react with surface reactive oxygen species to produce CO2. MnO x participates in the reaction through its oxidation state change, forming a redox cycle (Cu+ + Mn4+ ↔ Cu2+ + Mn3+). This redox system can cause rapid oxygen transfer that accelerates the oxidation of CO. OVs can adsorb O2 to generate surface reactive oxygen species. Some intermediates (carbonates and COO−) are formed during the reaction. 4 Conclusion In this work, it was proved the influence of preparation strategy on the catalytic performance of MnO x -CuO catalyst via three methods, redox precipitation, hydrothermal, and oxalate complexation. MnCu-YH showed excellent catalytic activity. When the temperature is 175 ℃, the CO conversion reached 100 %. The stability results showed that SO2 poisoned and deactivated the catalyst. When SO2 and H2O existed at the same time, H2O could delay the toxicity of the catalyst. XRD, HR-TEM, BET results indicated that MnCu-YH possessed a typical nanorod structure and the maximum specific surface area. XPS and H2-TPR studies revealed that MnCu-YH had the highest ratio of adsorbed oxygen and Mn3+, and excellent redox capacity. It could be put down to the fact that the redox system formed by Mn ion and Cu ion (Cu+ + Mn4+ ↔ Cu2+ + Mn3+) enhances the metal interaction between Mn and Cu, thereby serving as the fundamental factor for the enhanced CO oxidation activity of MnCu-YH. Besides, CO-TPD investigation showed that MnCu-YH has the most CO adsorption sites and is more likely to adsorb CO. In-situ DRIFTS results showed that MnCu-YH and MnCu-LH catalysts reacted with reaction gas at room temperature, while MnCu-SR catalyst only underwent an adsorption-desorption equilibrium process with the reaction gas. A catalytic mechanism for CO oxidation was proposed depending on in-situ DRIFTS characterization. As the adsorption site of CO, Cu+ formed CO-Cu+ species, which react with surface reactive oxygen species to produce CO2, and MnO x participated in the reaction through the change of its oxidation state. Some intermediates (carbonates and COO−) were formed during the reaction. This study focuses light on the effect of synthesis methods on the efficiency of MnO x - CuO catalysts. By comparing different synthesis strategies, the research emphasizes the remarkable potential of MnCu-YH for achieving efficient CO oxidation at low temperatures. MnCu-YH offers a promising and affordable alternative to traditional metal catalysts, making it highly attractive in large-scale industrial applications where performance and cost are key factors. coredata.dc:description: A series of MnO x -CuO catalysts were fabricated by redox precipitation (MnCu-YH), hydrothermal (MnCu-SR), and oxalate complexation methods (MnCu-LH) for low-temperature CO oxidation. The results showed that the MnCu-YH achieved 100 % CO conversion at 175 ℃ with WHSV of 60000 ml/ (g·h). It was also observed that SO2 could deactivate the catalyst, while H2O could delay the toxicity. Through the characterization of HR-TEM, XRD, BET, it was found that MnCu-YH possessed a typical nanorod structure and the largest specific surface area, measured at 45.54 m2·g−1. XPS and H2-TPR analyses revealed that MnCu-YH had the highest ratio of adsorbed oxygen and Mn3+, and excellent redox capacity, which were due to the redox cycle formed by Mn ions and Cu ions (Cu+ + Mn4+ ↔ Cu2+ + Mn3+). This redox cycle could strengthen the metal interaction between Mn and Cu, which is the fundamental factor driving the strong CO oxidation activity of MnCu-YH. Besides, CO-TPD investigation showed that MnCu-YH has the most CO adsorption sites and is more likely to adsorb CO. A catalytic mechanism for CO oxidation was proposed depending on in-situ DRIFTS characterization. As the adsorption site of CO, Cu+ formed CO-Cu+ species, which reacted with surface reactive oxygen species to produce CO2, and MnO x participated in the reaction by changing its oxidation state to cause oxygen transfer.
